moves.10. Nxd4 exd4: Symmetry was fun, but I'll keep my Queen thank you.  And I musn't forget my Knight is skewered to my Queen.
moves.11. Qd2: White is increasing pressure on f6 (my skewered Knight) so I must anticipate Qf4, which would tip the exchange in Whites' favor. So...
moves.11... c6: c6 should force an even exchange.
moves.14... Bxe2: A free pawn, and attack the Rook?  Yes, thank you, don't mind if I do.
moves.15. Rfc1 Rab8 16. Qd2 Bf3 17. Bxf3 Qxf3: I didn't expect the exchange, but I like the undoubled pawns.
moves.21. Re1 f6 22. a3 Re8 23. b4 f5 24. c5 e:
Interesting.  I could outflank with Qxa3.  But I would I like the pawn exchange?  NO!  White gains points and Center!

Do I Rxe4?  Maybe.  The Rook would protect vulnerable d4, and White would have few options, the most aggressive being Rxe4 which would leave my Queen parked in a good spot...

And last but not least, I cannot ignore the e4 Pawn.  exf5 exposes my Rook to his.
moves.25... Rxe4 26. a4:
I could play a5 and stop the advance, leaving a4 vulnerable to Qa3...
But without my Queen to support, a Rook exchange would leave my opponent up 1, instead of down 1! 

Perhaps I should initiate a Rook exchange.  We could trade Queens too, and start the pawn race... 

Qc3 looks promising - She attacks the Rook, Queen and Pawn in one fell swoop.   

But I think I like d3 best.  Pressing matters...
moves.27... f4 28. Rxe4: I think Black will regret this trade, for without that Rook....
moves.28... Qxe4: How can he stop my d3 pawn?
